In 1997, I robbed
a bank of $5,000.
It was my first offense.

But because armed
robbery is considered

a crime of violence,
I was sentenced

to 60 years in prison
without the possibility

of probation, parole or
suspension of sentence.
I missed a lot of things.

I missed first days of
school, birthday parties.

I missed holidays,
graduations.
I missed it all.

You might be thinking,
the guy robbed a bank.

Don’t do the crime if
you can’t do the time.
I agree.
I committed a wrong.

However, long, harsh,
lengthy sentences
do far more harm than good.

The United States is the
incarceration capital

of the world, and
Louisiana leads our nation.

Here in Louisiana, there
are more people serving life

without parole than Arkansas,
Alabama and Texas combined,

and almost 75 percent of
those lifers are Black.

The good news is,
Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards

is interested
in reforming
our criminal justice system.

Governor Edwards signed into
law a major criminal justice

reform package that was
aimed at reducing our prison
population.

But if he intends to
keep his promises,

he must work with the
legislature to pass a new law

ending life sentences
without parole,

even for violent
offenses like mine.

We set out with a dream of
opening a hip-hop clothing

store in our hometown of
Shreveport, La.,
and we did.

I was the happiest I had
ever been in my life,

until our investor
pulled out on us.

And desperate people
do desperate things.

We made the worst
decision of our lives.

But we are more than the worst
decision we have ever made.

For my role in the bank
robbery, I took a plea deal

and served three and
a half years in prison.

When you have a loved
one that is incarcerated,
the entire family does time.

We did 21 years every day,
day for day, with my husband.

And it was not a
minute or a moment

that his presence was not
missing from our lives.

The biggest travesty was that
I discovered that it wasn’t
just my family.

Far too many people across
this nation have our story.

And it’s also the first

Everybody talks about
the nuclear family

and the importance of
having Mom and Dad home,

My brothers and I

thanks to the love

But children of
incarcerated parents

are six times more likely
to get arrested themselves.

And after a certain point,
people age and mature

For instance, if you serve

The data and the
stats are clear,
life sentences aren’t helpful.

After 21 years in prison,
Governor Edwards granted
my clemency request.

And it was the best
day of my life.

But clemency for a few
individuals like me won’t fix
a broken system.

Life without parole isn’t
making us any safer,

and it’s costing taxpayers
billions of dollars.

Some U.S. states are
finally coming around.

A bill in Vermont could
make it the first state

to completely ban
life without parole.

And California recently
expanded parole opportunities
for aging offenders.

But Louisiana is the
incarceration capital
of the world.

If we can end life
sentences in Louisiana,
we can do it anywhere.

And to Governor Edwards,
I implore you to work with

our legislature to pass a
bill that ends life without
parole. Now.

And thank you for the lives

make our world a much better
place.
So for that, I salute you.

We can repair the criminal
justice system by letting
